  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours
    | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday
    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Hi everyone,
 
President Bush is pressuring Congress to salvage the
  immigration overhaul deal which was stalled last week after broad Republican
  opposition. Tonight Sharyl Attkisson will report that the President made a
  rare visit to the Capitol to nudge GOP senators on the bill. She’ll
  also explain how members of Congress are reacting to the pressure.
 
Also on Capitol Hill today, some military families
  testified before Congress about cancer and other illnesses they blame on
  drinking toxic tap water at their military base. Over three decades, the
  water at Camp Lejeune contained toxins at up to 40
  times the safety limit, federal investigators say. David Martin will have
  details.
 
It’s been more than a year since the
  allegations against Duke’s lacrosse team surfaced. But today, Durham County district attorney Mike Nifong
  was back in court – he’s been accused of violating rules of
  professional conduct, and if convicted, Nifong could be disbarred. Byron
  Pitts will have the story.
 
An FDA panel is set to meet tomorrow to decide
  whether an experimental diet drug should be sold in the United States. I’ll ask our
  Dr. Jon LaPook about the drug rimonabant, which would be sold under the name
  Zimulti.
 
Can’t wait to retire? You might have to wait
  longer than expected – and retire with less money than previous
  generations did. Nancy Cordes will look at the surprise that may be in store
  for the aging baby boomer population.
 
And Anthony Mason will have some details on the
  lavish perks – from stock options to bonuses – some executives
  rake in along with their salaries.
 
Finally, there’s a growing threat to the
  forests of mid-Atlantic states. And even though the villain is small, the
  damage can be enormous. Michelle Miller will have the story.
 
I hope you’ll join us for this and more,
 




Katie Couric
CouricandCo@cbs.com
